TEAM-ADA Archives

Team Ada: Ada Programming Language Advocacy


Options: Use Classic View

Use Mono...
output:
P.S.  The above example could be reduced to:

 A := F'Access;
B := A;
C := G'Access;
if A = B then -- Must be true.
if B = C then -- Must be false.
if B = A then -- Must be true.
if C = B then -- Must be false.
if A = A then -- Must be true.
if B = B then -- Must be true.
if C = C then -- Must be true.  :-)

 The last three statements are all true in all situations,
and the first four statements are all true in this situation.  So,
what good is it?  You've already determined the relationship
before the statement is even evaluated!  Why bother with the

 If the compiler determines that the above statements can't be
used, they will never appear in the generated code.  However,
the programmer might not know that, and might waste valuable
time coding and debugging them.  Why give them an option that
isn't useful?  If you're going to have a meaningless operator
anyway, make it something like "=" or "==" and use "=" for
the non-meaningless one.  I'd say that a compiler should
produce an error message when an equality check is coded
between two different access types.  And, if the compiler
can't determine which case it is, it should produce a warning
message.  It's better to be safe than sorry.

 I realize that "=" between two access types isn't meaningless
in all cases, but I think it's useless in most cases.  Why
make a feature available that is so rarely useful?

 Wes Groleau
 (wesley.groleau @ yahoo dot com)  Remove spaces from address to contact.  :-)

Bark damage to eastern redbud

Question Details
Category: Trees

Answer Accepted? Yes 640 Views

Other Answers (1)

0 Votes

In addition to the information provided by the previous answerer, I would like to add a couple of suggestions. First, if you are going to use pruning shears, loppers or a saw to remove the broken branches, make sure that these tools are very clean before using them. You can sterilize them with rubbing alcohol or a solution of one part bleach and nine parts water. Next, you can protect the open wounds on the branches and trunk by applying a non-drying tree wound dressing such as PVA glue. This will prevent insects and pathogens from entering the tree. You might also want to mulch the base of the tree with 3-4 inches of wood chips or shredded leaves, which will help protect the root system and conserve moisture. If your tree is young, keep grass and weeds from growing within a two foot radius of the trunk. Finally, be sure to water the tree when the soil is dry, especially if it has been windy, hot and dry for several days.

Answered on October 23, 2008
